results.title: Dorothea [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Anna Grieve, AFTRS and Wendy Chandler
results.brief_description: A young Greek woman, Dorothea, escapes her family’s resistance to adopting new ways and an arranged marriage by becoming involved in a theatre group and falling for the lead performer. Cast includes Helen Dullas, William Dye and Saavas Panas.
results.description: A young Greek woman, Dorothea, escapes her family’s resistance to adopting new ways and an arranged marriage by becoming involved in a theatre group and falling for the lead performer. Cast includes Helen Dullas, William Dye and Saavas Panas.

results.title: Doris Lessing
results.creator_credit: John Archer and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Well known writer Doris Lessing is interviewed about her life in Africa and the books she has written including “The grass is singing”, “The golden notebook”, “Briefing for a descent into hell”, and “Marriage between Zones 3,4 and 5”.

results.title: Dories
results.creator_credit: Whitman Trecartin, Rex Tasker, Mike Mahoney and Ted Haley
results.brief_description: Captain Albert Crouse, narrator of the film, used dories for fishing off the coast of Lunenberg, Nova Scotia. The film sketches the history of the dory. A local craftsman gives a step-by-step demonstration of the vessel’s construction

results.title: Doppler principles (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Air Training Command and Dept of the Air Force
results.brief_description: Uses animation to present the phenomenon of the Doppler effect. Explains the effects on a transmitted wave when it encounters a moving object or when the transmitter itself is moving. Also explains the Doppler effect when the target is moving at various angles to the transmitter.

results.title: Doppler effect
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
Explains the factors which determine the pitch of a sound. Waves are shown advancing toward the listener, and the following cases are treated: 1. Source and listener stationary; 2. Source in motion, listener stationary (accompanying change of wave-length and consequent change of apparent frequency are described in slow motion); 3. Source stationary, listener in motion (shows that no change in wave-length occurs, but that there is a change of apparent frequency).

results.title: Doodlin': impressions of Len Lye
results.creator_credit: Koninek and Energy Source, Channel 4 and Keith Griffiths
results.brief_description: Directed by Keith Griffiths, famous for his art documentaries and his work with the Brothers Quay and Jan Svankmajer, “Doodlin’” explores the life and works of Len Lye. The importance of the landscape and his early years living in New Zealand, Australia and Samoa are explored as well as his introduction to the avant garde of London and Europe generally and later those of New York where he moved to in the 1940’s. Lively interviews with his close friends and collaborators include: film maker Stan Brakhage, wife Ann Lye, composer Jack Ellit, editor Paul Barnes, artist Ray Thorburn, biographer Roger Horrocks and John Matthews who worked with Lye on the engineering of his kinetic sculpture. Lye discusses the process of Doodlin’ as a means to unlock the subconscious and his work being ‘old brain stuff’. Great footage and examples of Lye making films using his pioneering ‘direct film’ technique in the making of “Free radicals” and “Particles in Space” (both 1979). Footage of sculptures include: ‘Universe’ (1976), ‘Blade’ (1976), and ‘Trilogy’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Koninek and Energy Source, Channel 4 and Keith Griffiths

results.title: Doodle film
results.creator_credit: Robert Verrall, ONF | NFB and Donald Winkler
results.brief_description: The dossier of an inveterate doodler, a man whose compulsion to put scrawls and squiggles on everything at hand brings him to no good end, according to the narrator, at least. The commentary, delivered with the perspicacity of a coroner’s report, follows the development of the doodler’s mania from boyhood through adolescence to manhood, when it suddenly breaks all bounds. An amusing “case history” that some of us might identify with. Voice and narration provided by Maurice Podbrey. (Awards: Atlanta; Chicago)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Verrall, ONF | NFB and Donald Winkler

results.title: Donzoko = The Lower depths
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Shojiro Motoki and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description:
Gorky’s classic proletarian drama about human flotsam in a Moscow dosshouse living on illusions was revived by Kurosawa who injected new meaning into the adaptation of theatre to cinema. The film remains faithful to the text while transplanting the play into Tokyo of the Edo period. Kurosawa consciously brings out the humour not normally associated with the play but inherent in the gap between illusion and reality at the play’s centre. The Edo setting is deliberately ironic because it is a period that is usually romanticised by the Japanese. ‘The Lower Depths’ was filmed on only two sets but Kurosawa reconstitutes theatrical space in cinematic terms while retaining a deliberate theatricality in the use of sound and especially in performance. Acting is presentational rather than interpretational. Multiple cameras allowed the actors to maintain some continuity of performance (see also High and Low). See also, the version directed by Jean Renoir in 1936 (held in our collection). Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Producers, Shojiro Moroki, Akira Kurosawa ; director, Akira Kurosawa ; script, Hideo Oguni, Akira Kurosawa ; photography, Ichio Yamasaki ; music, Masaru Sato.
Cast: Toshiro Mifune, Isuzu Yamada, Ganjiro Nakamura.
